I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
1.  The Government of Uzbekistan has requested policy-based programmatic lending totaling 
$200 million from Asian Development Bank (ADB) concessional ordinary capital resources to 
support reforms to improve the enabling environment for small and medium-sized enterprise 
(SME) development. The reforms under the Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development 
Program are sequenced across two subprograms.1 The program is aligned with the government’s 
objective  of  increasing employment  and  real  incomes  across regions  of  the  country.2 The 
expected  outcome  of  the  program  is  an  improved  enabling  environment  for  SME  growth, 
diversification, and high-value-added job creation. The reform areas underlying the outcome are: 
(i) diversification of formal bank and nonbank financing instruments, (ii) reducing the institutional 
and administrative costs of doing business, (iii) improving trade facilitation and digitalization, and 
(iv) aligning skills development with market needs. The effect of the reforms will be diversified 
economic growth and high-value-added jobs. The program and the technical assistance (TA) are 
included in the country operations business plan for Uzbekistan, 2021–2023.3 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
2.   ADB has supported SMEs and microenterprises in Uzbekistan since 1996, primarily 
through loans and TA. The focus has been on financing working capital and the acquisition of 
fixed assets and improving the financial and technical capacity of the participating financial 
institutions to serve SMEs better. Implementation lessons show that access to finance is only one 
of several key constraints to SME development in the country. Hence, ADB should complement 
its credit lines (financial intermediation loans) with policy-based operations to catalyze critical 
sectoral, policy, and institutional reforms. Cross-cutting reforms are critical for SMEs to join the 
formal economy and create high-value-added jobs across a range of sectors. 
 
3.  Uzbekistan’s gross domestic product (GDP) averaged 6.2% during 2010–2020, with GDP 
 
growth slowing to 1.6% in 2020 because of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.4 This 
growth has been accompanied by rising incomes of SMEs and microenterprises, regular minimum 
wage increases, and social safety nets to cushion the impacts of structural reforms underway 
since  2017.  Supported  by  government  policy  to  develop  the  private  sector,  the  role  and 
contribution of SMEs in the economy has been expanding.5 About 411,203 SMEs were registered 
and active at the end of 2020, up 4% from 2019. SMEs accounted for 54% of GDP during 2019–
2020, contributing  97% in agriculture, 82% in trade, 72% in construction, and 52% in services. 
SMEs accounted for 27% of exports and 62% of imports in 2020. They are the largest employers 
and provided 78% of formal and informal jobs combined in 2018, up from 50% in 2000.6 
 
4.  SME development and state-owned enterprise reform, key pillars of the government’s 
private sector development strategy, are being undertaken in parallel in Uzbekistan. Since 2017,

key reforms have been underway to improve ease of doing business. In the Doing Business 2020 
report, the country ranked 69th globally, up from 76th place in 2018, with higher scores than the 
previous year in nine of the 10 assessment criteria.7 Commencing in January 2019, tax system 
distortions that unfairly burdened small businesses were removed. Trading across borders was 
eased  using  risk-based  inspections,  simplifying  import  documentary  requirements,  and 
harmonizing  19,000  out  of  30,000  internal technical  regulation,  certification,  and  metrology 
standards with international norms to improve product quality and enter world markets. Given the 
severe impact of COVID-19 on SMEs in Uzbekistan, the government is keen to further reform the 
SME enabling environment to prevent the reversal of gains in SME development, which have 
fueled economic growth, and increase SMEs' resilience to future economic shocks.8   
 
5.  The government requested TA to support government initiatives to implement critical 
reforms in selected areas of the Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program.9 
The results framework, implementation arrangements, cost estimate, and scope of the TA, in 
relation to the proposed program, were discussed with the government during consultation 
meetings for the policy-based loan.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Operation and governance of the guarantee scheme under the State Fund 
for Support of Entrepreneurship strengthened. This output will support implementation of 
reforms in the institutional structure and the operational and governance framework in the existing 
partial credit guarantee scheme (PCG) to ensure financial sustainability, appropriate outreach, 
and increased access to credit. This will include developing, based on international good practices: 
(i) eligibility criteria for participating financial institutions and SMEs; (ii) a risk management 
framework including credit risk assessment of SMEs and exposure limits per sector, region, and 
participating financial institution; (iii) a governance framework; (iv) pricing and fee policy; (v) an 
operational framework; (vi) a guarantee procedure and claims management process; and (vii) a 
monitoring and evaluation system including independent auditing. The required legal/regulatory 
framework will also be assessed. These changes will be based on recommendations from the 
qualitative and quantitative analysis undertaken by the State Fund, with support of ADB, in 2020. 
 
7.  Output  2:  Institutional  structure  and  operations  of  the  Entrepreneurship 
Development Agency rationalized and improved. This output will help improve the operations 
and efficiency of the Entrepreneurship Development Agency (EDA). This will include support for 
(i) implementing the SME development strategy in line with the government’s development 
strategy (footnote 2); (ii) long-term financial planning to ensure that the agency would not be at 
risk in the event of a change of government; (iii) operationalizing a system for collecting and 
analyzing sex-disaggregated data to better target policy interventions for SMEs in a specific group, 
sector, size, or class; and (iv) enhancing the quality and legitimacy of its services by including on 
 
7  World Bank. 2020. Doing Business 2020: Comparing Business Regulation in 190 Economies. Washington, DC. 
8  SMEs experienced a sharp decline in sales and depletion of cash reserves because of the pandemic and associated 
lockdowns, especially from March to October 2020. More than half of SMEs (52.7%) experienced a decline in demand 
for their products and 62.2% suffered a revenue decline. The number of permanent personnel of SMEs declined by 
6.3% from March to October 2020, and 34.7% of SMEs had to lay off staff. Most of the employment reduction was 
by SMEs in manufacturing, furniture, textiles, apparel, leather products and rendering, accommodation, catering, 
entertainment, transportation and storage, education and science, construction and building materials, plumbing, and 
trade. The aggregate unemployment rate rose from 9.0% in 2019 to 10.5% in 2020. The decline in demand for SMEs’ 
products, and related decline in revenues, in urban areas was more severe compared with rural areas. Nearly 60% 
of SME exporters either reduced or stopped their exports during the pandemic. Exports in services and construction 
were hit hardest, followed by agriculture, trade, and industry. 
9  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 25 December 2021.

3 
its decision-making bodies representatives from financial institutions, universities, technology 
centers, business associations, and other stakeholders. 
 
8.  Output 3. Uptake of digitalization and eco-Innovation in small and medium-sized 
enterprises increased. This output will strengthen the capacity of the Department of Nonfinancial 
Support to Entrepreneurship under EDA to support (i) increased digitalization of SMEs, and (ii) 
adoption of green technologies through "soft" interventions (i.e., nonfinancial, such as advice, 
training, and networking) and "hard" interventions (i.e., financial).10 For (i), EDA will establish a 
formal coordination mechanism with IT-Park Uzbekistan to raise SMEs’ awareness of the benefits 
of adopting digitalized solutions and applying a broad range of technologies for different purposes 
(e.g., to enable greater access to markets and end-users; to integrate business processes; to 
improve customer service and relationship management; to improve supply chain management; 
to increase business visibility; to implement electronic invoicing; to implement incubation and 
acceleration programs for local information technology (IT) startups; and to access public and 
private venture funds, info-education, startup hackathons, and other events). EDA will also 
develop a platform for expertise and knowledge transfer by mapping companies that have 
successfully digitalized their processes and services. For (ii), EDA will provide assistance to link 
SMEs to advice, training, and networking to improve their understanding of the links between 
business and the environment and the costs, benefits, and resources available to help them 
overcome barriers in adopting green technologies. EDA will also develop mechanisms to support 
the State Fund to finance digitalization and SME investments in green technologies (such as 
thermal  insulation,  photovoltaic  solar  panels,  geothermal  heat  pumps,  and  water-efficient 
irrigation systems). 
 
9.  Output 4. Action plan for implementing International Financial Reporting Standards 
for SMEs developed. This output will support the Ministry of Finance to develop a detailed action 
plan to implement International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) for SMEs, as required 
under Government Resolution No. 4611 (adopted in 2020).11 IFRS for SMEs will strengthen 
SMEs' financial management and reporting capacity and improve their access to finance. The TA 
will undertake assessments to identify gaps between IFRS for SMEs and national accounting 
standards for SMEs. Workshops and webinars will be undertaken to (i) train the trainers in using 
IFRS for SMEs training material, and (ii) train accountants and specialists to apply IFRS for SMEs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $265,000, of which $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office  accommodation,  inter-agency  coordination,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
10 In accordance with the Digital Uzbekistan–2030 strategy, passed in 2021, the government is prioritizing the 
development of information technology entrepreneurship, particularly youth entrepreneurship. The government has 
allocated financing for stable and high‐speed internet access, development of business infrastructure, and adequate 
office premises. A network of coworking office spaces is also being established in every region of the country to 
provide entrepreneurs with digital communication infrastructure.  
11 IFRS for SMEs are a set of accounting standards developed by the International Accounting Standards Board 
designed for SMEs for general purpose financial statements and reporting to lenders and government authorities. 
Joint-stock companies, commercial banks, insurance organizations and legal entities classified as large taxpayers 
and business entities with a state share and state-owned enterprises approved by the State Assets Management 
Agency are required to prepare financial statements applying IFRS Standards. Other companies may voluntarily 
prepare financial statements applying IFRS Standards. For SMEs, reporting as per national standards is required.

4      
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division 
of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants. 
 
12.  The State Fund and EDA (under the Ministry of Economic Development and Poverty 
Reduction) and the Ministry of Finance will be the primary implementing agencies for the TA. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.
